transcripts.text: Let's bring in the power players to get a take.  Gloria Borger, what's the big headline?
Bloomberg was awful.  The notion, even for a Mike Bloomberg, that you can step in and go toe-to-toe on this stage with people who've been doing it, what, Andrew Yang, for a couple of years.
Yes, a couple of years.  For a couple of years.
It seems to me that that was difficult for him.
Andrew Yang, you know the field the best.  You know what it's like on that stage.  What was the read?

I think three things happened to Mike tonight.  Number one, he just found out he'd make the debate yesterday.  There were two times when I wasn't sure if I was going to make the debate and my team got me together to prepare.  And you're really not sure if you're preparing because you're like, I'm not sure if I'm going to be in this debate.  So Mike, even though he was, I'm sure, getting coached and prepared, he was like, I don't know if I'm going to be in this debate.  And so I don't think he was coached hard enough.  Number two, he was clearly instructed to keep his cool no matter what.  But that ended up presenting as being lethargic and uninterested for a big chunk of the debate.  And the third most telling thing is that if I'm his team, you know he's going to get a stop and frisk question, like a gender discrimination or mistreatment question.  So you coach him and you have him give you 60, 75 second answers over and over again until he can do it in his sleep.  And the fact that he did not have those answers at his fingertips lets me know categorically he was not properly prepared.
Well, they say they coached him on all of those all of those issues.
So that he had extensive debate.  Exactly.  With real mock debates, with his aides playing all the roles of all the people.
Listen, this was a disaster for Bloomberg.

Let me come back to you.  There's a difference, and you guys know this very well, between being prepped and accepting the preparation.  Do you believe that Bloomberg doesn't know how to answer these questions or doesn't accept what his team wants the answers to be?  There's a meaningful distinction.

There really is a distinction, Chris, and it's very apt because you can only be coached if you're willing to be coached.  I mean, everyone who works for Bloomberg works for Bloomberg.  So there's no one that could be like, hey, Mike, you have to like, yeah, that was terrible.  You have to do it again.  We're going to videotape you and show it to you.  Did that happen with you?  Yes, that happened to me.  And then you don't let the person leave the room.  And the people who are working with me worked for me too, but they knew that I was coachable.  If they were like, hey, Yang, that was not great.  Here, we'll show it to you.  Let's do it again.  Then I'd be like, all right, let's do it again.  And there were times I did not want to be there at all.  But in Mike's case, if he didn't want to be there, he's not going to be there.  You know what I mean?  There's no one on his team who can be like, that was terrible.  This is going to potentially damage your campaign to a very, very high degree.  And you need to not, and I know this is the case because I saw him on stage.  If you get the obvious question and you don't pivot to this memorized script that your team has hammered into you, then you just did not get prepared or you were not willing to prepare yourself.
He did, but he wasn't ready for the fallout.

But I have to tell you something.  You have to think about it in terms of willingness versus readiness.  Warren has been identified as the best political athlete on the stage.  Love you, brother.  But I'm saying in terms of, you know, what she what she can do, skill for skill, toe to toe.  It has not resonated.
The quote is, I don't think there's a chance of the senator beating President Trump.  If he goes and is the candidate, we'll have Donald Trump for another four years.  And we can't stand that.
Andrew, is that true?

Well, that's his argument.  And there are a lot of Democrats with the argument.  There are a lot of Democrats who are concerned that if you have Bernie at the top of the ticket, it's going to mean a very, very tough night in a lot of swing states.
Do you think it's a fair concern or do you think it's more about what they're used to versus watching a movement in their midst?

I think it's a fair concern.  based upon the polling data that shows that Bernie will underperform in various swing states the Democrats highly, highly value.  I want to tell a Mike Bloomberg story because we were talking about how he hasn't had all these days in the town halls and the living rooms and whatnot.  Back when he was considering running, you know, more than 12 months ago, he actually took trial trips to New Hampshire and Iowa to see if he could relate to the people and he concluded that it was not his thing.  And then he said, hey, I'm not running.  And it was only more recently that he changed his mind on that.  So he's a very smart, data-driven guy.  He went and got the data.  The data was not very promising at that point.  And I think, unfortunately, that manifests itself tonight on the debate stage.

Bernie versus Bloomberg.  I think whatever happens tonight, what you're seeing is that there's a judgment on this party.  And, you know, frankly, one of the people I have the most hope in is you because you had a different set of ideas.  But the people should be looking in the mirror in this party to figure out what is going on here, because really we should have other choices than just these two outsiders.

We're back here with the power players.  We shouldn't lose all sensitivity.  Andrew, this is you watching it in a totally different way now that you joined the CNN team.  What is it like for you watching it up there on stage and the feeling of what if I had been there versus being here?  What's that like?

Well, I certainly miss being on the debate stage on many levels.  But we were talking about Mike Bloomberg's experience and how I actually anticipated he was going to have a tough night, in part because of the timing of his qualification.  And then looking at his campaign schedule, where if you're campaigning, you're campaigning, and then someone says, hey, we've set aside this time to prepare for the debate, it's actually very hard to get into debate mode.  It's almost like another mindset.  And to me, the big mistake they made, and this is going to sound possibly controversial, but I thought they should have advised him to skip this debate.  I thought they should have just said, look, I'm not on the Nevada ballot.  This is going to confuse voters.  We'll see you in the next one.  And then some people would have given him a hard time about it.  But then he would have had a genuine runway to actually try and get, frankly, prepared to have a better night.  And to me, that was the missed opportunity.  They should have just said, look, I'm going to skip Nevada.  No, great.
He agrees with you, the campaign.

He just put out a statement saying about Bloomberg, he was just warming up tonight.  We fully expect Mike will continue to build on tonight's performance when he appears on the stage in South Carolina next Tuesday.
Oh, that's devastating.  Usually your inbox is full of every candidate saying that they have won the debate.
You know you're a winner when you're drawing attacks from all the candidates.  But that's the most important part of the statement.
That's a very modest spin.
That is D-spin, I think.  For the first eight debates, it was kid gloves.  I mean, they didn't go really well.  There were a couple of shots, but not really much.
It goes to fans' idea, doesn't it?

Yeah, I agree with Terry that a lot of them were coached at, look, let it all hang out tonight.  This could be the last debate.  This is existential.  Right.  And it actually showed in some of their performance.  Like you could tell Elizabeth was very, very fired up.
Elizabeth was like, tonight I settle all family business.

What is the best way to measure what the impact of a night is?  And not surprisingly, Andrew Yang said, I'll tell you what's going to matter.  And interestingly, Bloomberg's asset is money.  You're saying that's what matters after the debate.  What has to happen for someone to know that it worked for them?

I thought Elizabeth Warren had a tremendous night.  They announced they raised $425,000 in the first hour of the debate.  But that means that she's going to raise probably $1, $2, $3, $4 million in the days after the debate.  And she needs to raise $20, $30, $40 million if she's going to contend in the Super Tuesday states that have very expensive media markets.  That's why Bloomberg has so much power in this race, is that he can put ads up in all these states that every other candidate is not going to be able to afford.
People don't have any money.  You're shaking your head.  You know this story.
I do.
And who has the money to compete other than Bernie Sanders right now and Michael Bloomberg?

That's.  the great question is could Elizabeth or Joe or Amy or Pete have some kind of breakout night that led to tens of millions of dollars in donations, not just from people watching at home, but also donors who are on the sidelines right now, frankly, getting phone calls from Mike Bloomberg saying, hey, sit this one out.  I got this.  And if you're a donor, not donating is actually a pretty appealing pitch.  Yeah.
I'll do it.  Can you say that again?
Mike Bloomberg is calling donors saying, don't give to my opponents?
Mike Bloomberg is calling donors saying, hey, just sit this one out.  I've got this.  I'll bankroll the whole thing.  Just don't donate to anybody.
You hear this?  You know this?

I heard this from a major donor.  Your donor.  Yes.  Like Adora said that.  And it's a person who donates to, you know, a number of candidates ordinarily said that these are the phone calls that might.

One of the rule changes in the game now is that when you say something, we don't just say, are you sure?  We say, where did you hear it?  Because on the analysis side, we've got to make sure we're putting something out that we can verify.  So Andrew is, of course, correct that you have to manifest your success in money.  Bernie Sanders party about billionaires should go and obviously Mike Bloomberg giving a different perspective.  Andrew, how did it play for you?

To me, it's a struggle for the soul of the Democratic Party, and it mirrors what happened to the Republican Party in the last cycle, where you had Donald Trump, the outsider, who's running roughshod over all these traditional candidates who were putting up Republican talking points, and it turned out that their ideas just weren't that powerful anymore.  And this time you have Bernie... the outsider, the front runner now, poised to run the table.  And the establishment's been looking around for a white knight, and Bloomberg has shown up with all of his money, all of his wealth, all of his TV ads.  And to me, this was a great night for Bernie because Bernie emerges as the front runner.  He's really hard to touch, Bernie.  I mean, I've been on the debate stage with him seven times, and he's just like a stoic messenger.  Like, it doesn't matter what you say to him.  He'll just pivot right back to one of his Bernie-esque talking points.  And then the minute passes.

Elizabeth Warren, that was a taste of what she did basically to everybody on that stage, once again proving that she is arguably the best political athlete that the party may have.  But the question becomes, is what you just saw enough to make her money?  in a position where she can be competitive.  Let's take it to the bigger minds.  Now, Andrew, you've been giving us the practicality of this.  A little bit of update on what we understand.  The Bernie Sanders campaign posted the best fundraising night of any debate yet, 2.7 million, they say, from 150,000 donations.  It's according to spokesperson Kaska.  The Elizabeth Warren campaign had its best fundraising day ever.  according to a tweet from Caitlin Mitchell, Warren's chief mobilization officer.  More than a million dollars during the debate.

Yeah, those are really impressive sums.  The question is whether she's going to get another million in the hours after the debate and then another million and then another million and then another million, because the advertising buys she would need to make in some of the big markets on Super Tuesday are really expensive, like California, Texas.  I was just sharing an anecdote about how the Bloomberg campaign has just been hoovering up staff from every campaign, including mine, paying way above market rate.  They're almost like a big company that's doing roll-ups or acquisitions, but the acquisitions are actually political staff.  And, you know, I wouldn't be surprised if many of the candidates on the stage tonight were losing staff to Bloomberg because he's offering 150 to 200 percent of what the market rate is essentially at every level.

So it's not just.  it's not just the not just the advertising.  I mean, people think about him.  They're talking about, yeah, he's buying up all the ads.  He's buying up all the talent in the Democratic Party.  I've heard that that's actually causing some problems.  People trying to run for state Senate and stuff like that.  They can't actually down ballot.
But they have to want to work for him.  Right?  Or is the money enough where they're just going to work for him just so that they get through the cycle?
If you're a political operative, I mean, you work for a lot of candidates, yeah.  Really.

Wow.  Bloomberg, I think, got really wrong.  He was really tone deaf on some of these questions around class, around income.  Yeah, when he said, I worked really hard, and that's why I have all this money.  You know what, buddy?  There's a lot of people who are working really hard who don't have all that money.  When he had the little thing around, well, I can't possibly figure out a way to count all my money.
At this stage, we've only had two contests.  They are trying to dig down to their supporters.  It's getting late early, Terry.  It's getting late early.

It is late early, but hold on.  It's late early for us also.  So let's get in one more break here.  When we come back, we're going to have... You should have stayed in.  Maybe Yang's going to get back in the race.  Stay tuned for the answer to that question right after this.

Get some of that Cuomo money.  Yeah, you have to shoot ads.  You have to make the media buy.  You need some lead time.  To me, a lot of the problem is that you have several moderates who are congesting the lane where Bernie is capped out at around, let's call it 25% to 30%.  But then because you have Joe and Amy and Pete all in there and Mike now... You need to consolidate that group of four candidates, but then who gets out for who?  It's a collective action problem, and each of them has, obviously, a team that has zero interest in saying, we're going to get out for another candidate.  But if they all stay, then you can see Bernie running away with this.
Do you get out, Elizabeth?  I mean, not Elizabeth.
Do you get out, Amy?
Or do you get out, Pete?  Or do you get out, Joe?  Or, well, Bloomberg doesn't have to sit at that table.  It's never going to happen.  It's never going to happen, right?  Never.
At this point, they're all equally plausible candidates.
They're also kind of equally cash-strapped.

Right.  I'll tell you that these conversations are going to start heating up over the next one to two weeks because they're seeing the same calendar.  It's like almost like this wall and they're like this wave that's about to crash into it.  So they're having much more serious conversations.  You could tell from tonight that they were all told, look, this could be make or break for your campaign.  And if you're in that mode, then honestly, I think.  We're going to see some of these candidates having very, very tough conversations, hopefully even with other campaigns.
You were part of that club until recently.
Yes, I was.

Do you see what Gloria just suggested?  I mean, which is very logical ever happening.  The people who are there remaining in the congested lane that you discussed having a meeting and saying, let's talk about I'll get out.  Who's going to stay in?

No, I don't see it.  You know, I know the people involved, you know, like they don't have those kinds of relationships with each other.  And again, they each have a team of dozens, hundreds of people that have interests that are very much the opposite direction because they're all trying to think, hey, if my person becomes the president or Veep, then, you know, we're going to have this job, that job, that job.  This is still the hope and the dream.  So it's going to be tough to get them all together.  But if they don't come together in some way, then I think the timing is going to end up working out for Bernie.
Exactly what happened in 2016 with the Republican Party.
Andrew Yang, my favorite group, Tribe Called Quest has a line.  You're a box of positives.  You're a big plus, love.  Thank you very much for joining the team.  You are value added.
Put the money in our heads.  Put the money in our heads.  Put the money in our heads.  Put the money in our heads.
Can we afford it?
Yes.  Will it cause inflation?  No.  Is it awesome?  Yes.
Anyone trying to make it happen?  Yeah, that guy.
